message.content: For every integer $\alpha$, there exist polynomials $p$ and $q$ such that the sum of the squares of their evaluations at $\alpha$ equals $-1$.
For every integer $\alpha$, there exist polynomials $p$ and $q$ such that the sum of the squares of their evaluations at $\alpha$ equals $-1$.

For every integer $\alpha$, there exist polynomials $p$ and $q$ such that the sum of the squares of their evaluations at $\alpha$ is equal to $-1$; i.e., $\exists p, q$ such that $\text{Polynomial.eval}(\alpha, p)^2 + \text{Polynomial.eval}(\alpha, q)^2 = -1$.

The theorem states that for every integer $\alpha$, there exist polynomials $p$ and $q$ such that the sum of the squares of their evaluations at $\alpha$ equals $-1$.
For every integer $\alpha$, there exist polynomials $p$ and $q$ such that the evaluation of $p$ at $\alpha$ squared plus the evaluation of $q$ at $\alpha$ squared equals $-1$.
